Additionally, Companies House Form LIQ03 can be used to give notice of a progress report in a voluntary winding-up, which may be relevant if you decide to pursue a voluntary winding-up instead of contesting the petition. It's essential to note that the court's primary concern is the interests of the creditors. Therefore, you will need to demonstrate that the proposed investment and restructuring plan will benefit the creditors and ensure that the company can pay its debts. I recommend that you seek the advice of a qualified insolvency lawyer to discuss your options in more detail and to determine the best course of action for your company.

In terms of your brother's offer, it's essential to ensure that the sale of the business is done at a fair price and that all creditors are treated fairly. You may want to consider seeking independent advice to ensure that the sale is conducted in a way that complies with the Insolvency Act 1986 and the Companies Act 2006. Lastly, you should be aware of the potential consequences of not addressing your debt burden. If your business is wound up, you may be personally liable for some of the debts, and your credit rating could be affected. I recommend seeking advice from a qualified insolvency practitioner or a solicitor who specializes in insolvency law to help you navigate this complex situation. It is also worth noting that you may be able to apply for a moratorium under Insolvency Act 1986 section A4, which could give you some breathing space to restructure your business and avoid winding up.
